title: Rikers replacement plan clears committee, heads to full Council
text:
The plan needs 26 votes to pass, but as many as 14 members are considering voting against it and others remain undecided, per recent reports. | Getty Images Rikers replacement plan clears committee, heads to full Council

The City Council's land use committee approved the de Blasio administration’s plan to close Rikers Island on Wednesday, ahead of what is expected to be a close vote of the full Council Thursday.

The plan calls for constructing four borough-based detention facilities over the next seven years to house a jail population the city expects will shrink dramatically by then. City Hall has reduced the size of the proposed facilities, added a guarantee that Rikers will in fact close and promised a range of other investments to appease critics.

Story Continued Below

“We believe that in securing this broad set of commitments, the Council sends a strong message that we understand our new approach must go beyond new jail buildings,” Council member Adrienne Adams, chairwoman of the landmarks and dispositions subcommittee, said at a committee hearing Wednesday.

But the proposal continues to face opposition from a vocal contingent of activists who oppose the construction of any new jails, even though the plan will result in a net decrease in city detention facilities. They have prominent supporters including Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who came out against the city’s plan earlier this month.

The Council members who represent the areas surrounding the planned jails support the proposal, and all four — Steve Levin, Margaret Chin, Karen Koslowitz and Diana Ayala — spoke in favor of the plan at a subcommittee meeting Wednesday.

Despite the Council’s tradition of deferring to local members on land use applications, it is not a given that the plan will win full Council approval. The plan needs 26 votes to pass, but as many as 14 members are considering voting against it and others remain undecided, per recent reports.

Council land use chairman Rafael Salamanca voted against the plan on Wednesday, as did Council Members Inez Barron, Andy King, Ruben Diaz Sr., and Chaim Deutsch. Some argued the proposal does not address the root inequities in the criminal justice system.

Members who voted in support of the plan said closing Rikers is only the first step of a broader overhaul of the city jail system.

“There will not be another opportunity to vote to close Rikers in the near future,” said Council Member Mark Treyger. “I do not have confidence that there’s the political and bureaucratic will to close Rikers outside of this vote.”

Glenn Martin, an early advocate for closing Rikers, sent an email to Council members this morning urging them to vote down the $8.7 billion plan.

“The purpose of my work was never only to shutter Rikers, and certainly not to construct 4 new Torture Towers,” he wrote. “At a cost of $300,000 per bed per year, Rikers will eventually close, but the important question is ‘and then what?’ You hold the answer to that question with your vote. Member deference is where dreams go to die.”

Dana Rubinstein contributed to this report.
description: The proposal continues to face opposition from a vocal contingent of activists who oppose the construction of any new jails.
